revised_title: Symbiotic Interface and Nutrient Exchange in Algae-Invertebrate Symbiosis
tldr: The study investigates the symbiotic relationship between the dinoflagellate alga Symbiodinium and the sea anemone Anemonia viridis. Both the algal and animal cell membranes have ATPase activity, suggesting that they can control the flux of nutrients across the symbiotic interface. The symbiosome membrane may play a significant role in controlling the availability of phosphorous compounds and other nutrients to the alga. This challenges the diffusion-depletion hypothesis, which proposes that symbiont demand is the primary determinant of nutrient supply to the symbiont cells.
